qas.question: The precursor of the nervous system is called what in vertebrates?
The neural groove is a hollow cord of cells with what in the center?
The forebrain splits during development into vesicles called what?

answers.text: telencephalon (which will contain the cerebral cortex, basal ganglia, and related structures) and the diencephalon

qas.question: The vesicle that contains the cerebral cortex is which one?
The thalamus and hypothalamus are contained in which vesicle?

context: For vertebrates, the early stages of neural development are similar across all species. As the embryo transforms from a round blob of cells into a wormlike structure, a narrow strip of ectoderm running along the midline of the back is induced to become <a0_0>the neural plate<a0_0/>, the precursor of the nervous system. The neural plate folds inward to form the neural groove, and then the lips that line the groove merge to enclose the neural tube, a hollow cord of cells with a <a1_0>fluid-filled ventricle<a1_0/> at the center. At the front end, the ventricles and cord swell to form three vesicles that are the precursors of the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain. At the next stage, the forebrain splits into two vesicles called the <a2_0><a3_0>telencephalon<a3_0/> (which will contain the cerebral cortex, basal ganglia, and related structures) and <a4_0>the diencephalon<a4_0/><a2_0/> (which will contain the thalamus and hypothalamus). At about the same time, the hindbrain splits into the metencephalon (which will contain the cerebellum and pons) and the myelencephalon (which will contain the medulla oblongata). Each of these areas contains proliferative zones where neurons and glial cells are generated; the resulting cells then migrate, sometimes for long distances, to their final positions.
